parts: Can I use sewing machine oil to oil my grandfather clock

No, it's not recommended to use sewing machine oil on your grandfather clock. Sewing machine oil is formulated for high-speed, small mechanical parts, while grandfather clocks have different mechanisms that need a specialized clock oil designed for low-speed, large pivot points. Using sewing machine oil might temporarily work, but it could actually damage the clock over time by causing gumming or attracting dust, leading to wear on the clockâ€™s mechanisms. 

A quality clock oil, specifically for larger mechanical movements, will ensure that it runs smoothly and prolong its lifespan.

No, definitely avoid using WD-40 on your grandfather clock! WD-40 is a penetrating oil and water displacer, designed to loosen rusted parts and provide temporary lubrication, not for delicate clock mechanisms. It can actually break down any existing proper clock oil, attract dust and grime, and potentially cause long-term damage to the clock's movement.

Instead, go with a high-quality clock oil. Applying it sparingly to the pivots and specific moving parts will keep the clock running well without damaging it.
